title: Update curl command in PowerShell documentation for inbound agent to use curl.exe
body:
The current documentation for setting up an inbound agent on Windows using PowerShell recommends the `curl` command. However, in PowerShell, `curl` is an alias for `Invoke-WebRequest`, which does not support the same flags (e.g., `-sO`) as the standalone curl executable. This causes the command to fail unexpectedly.

To address this, the documentation now specifies `curl.exe` instead of `curl` for PowerShell users, ensuring the correct executable is invoked. A note has also been added to clarify that `curl.exe` is included by default in newer Windows versions (e.g., Windows 10 version 1803 and later). For older versions, users may need to install curl separately.

Reference: [Microsoft's note on curl in PowerShell](https://curl.se/windows/microsoft.html)

### Update Log

- Updated the PowerShell example from `curl` to `curl.exe` to ensure compatibility with the required flags.
- Added a note explaining that `curl` is a PowerShell alias for `Invoke-WebRequest`, while `curl.exe` is the standalone executable.
- Specified that this change applies only to PowerShell; `curl` works as expected in CMD.
